description: A winter inversion is trapping pollution in Salt Lake City, pushing air quality to the worst levels in the U.S. this week.

pages.title: Salt Lake City is facing its worst air quality in the United States this week, as a thick winter haze blankets the entire valley.

pages.description: On Tuesday, air quality in Salt Lake City ranked worst in the nation. Monitors showed pollution levels high enough to be classified as unhealthy for sensitive groups.
The pollution is being trapped by a temperature inversion. Cold air has settled near the ground, while warmer air above it is preventing normal air circulation.
Salt Lake City sits in a basin surrounded by mountains. This geography blocks wind and allows polluted air to remain trapped close to the surface for days.
During stagnant weather, emissions from vehicles, factories, oil refineries, and residential fireplaces build up instead of dispersing.
Meteorologists say the city has not experienced a major inversion in several years, making this prolonged period of dirty air feel especially severe.
Forecasts suggest the poor air quality will continue through the weekend and possibly into next week. Only strong winds or a significant storm system are likely to clear the valley.
Exposure to fine particle pollution can worsen asthma, trigger heart problems, and increase the risk of respiratory illness, especially with prolonged exposure.
Children, older adults, pregnant women, outdoor workers, and people with heart or lung conditions face higher health risks during periods of elevated pollution.

Transportation accounts for nearly half of wintertime particulate pollution in the Salt Lake Valley. Reducing driving can make a meaningful difference.
Studies show that long-term exposure to polluted air in Utah is linked to shorter life expectancy, higher healthcare costs, and billions of dollars in economic losses.
Until weather conditions change, the polluted air is likely to remain. Staying informed and taking precautions can help reduce health risks.
